headline: Correction
summary: "How Could the Fort Hood Massacre Happen?," an op-ed by Sens. Joseph Lieberman and Susan Collins on Monday, April 26, incorrectly identifies Fort Recovery as being in Indiana. It is in Ohio.

headline: Lincoln Center Duplex
summary: The newlywed owner of this two-bedroom duplex with unobstructed views of Central Park received this apartment as a gift from her parents, but says it's time to cut the apron strings.

headline: Five Must-Ask Interview Questions
summary: As the economy picks up, companies are starting to hire more. But managers often only get funds for a few key hires, so they must select new employees wisely.

headline: Citi Makes Australia Hires
summary: Citigroup announced two senior hires in Australia and New Zealand, including a well-known UBS banker, as it attempts to beef up its institutional clients coverage in the region.

headline: Five Rules for Making Smart Hires
summary: Managers are finally getting the chance to hire -- but they need to make their choices count. Here are five rules for making smart hires.

headline: Mexico's Lower House Approves Competition Law Reforms
summary: Mexico's lower house of Congress on Thursday approved legislation that will give the country's anti-trust agency greater powers to punish firms and executives that violate competition laws.

headline: Sales Fall but Motorola Upbeat
summary: Motorola reported a first-quarter profit as a stronger economy lifted its enterprise divisions and the slow turnaround continued at its marquee handset unit.

headline: FDA Clears Cancer Treatment
summary: The FDA approved Dendreon's Provenge, a new type of prostate cancer treatment designed to use a patient's own cells to stimulate the body's immune system to fight the cancer.

headline: Starbucks Mounts Major Grocery Push
summary: Starbucks is rolling out Via instant coffee to tens of thousands of supermarkets and other outlets in coming weeks, as the company aims to put more products in grocery aisles.

headline: H-P Joins a Two-Front Fray
summary: H-P's acquisition of Palm highlights how big technology companies are increasingly engaged in a two-front war to dominate the consumer and corporate tech markets.

headline: Amazon, Penguin in Flap
summary: Amazon has begun selling a number of new hardcovers published by Penguin Group (USA) for only $9.99 amid a dispute over electronic books.

headline: Consumer Products Price War
summary: Procter & Gamble is waging an aggressive market-share war, cutting prices, accelerating product launches and spending more on advertising. P&G sales rose 7% in the latest quarter. Unilever profits jumped 33%.

headline: Woolworths Sales Climb
summary: Woolworths's third-quarter sales rose, and the Australian retail giant backed its earnings forecast while cutting some growth targets.

headline: FDA Faulted in Heparin Case
summary: The FDA didn't pursue leads that might have identified culprits in China during the 2008 heparin crisis, a congressional investigation found.

headline: Microsoft Tablet Project Shelved
summary: Microsoft has shelved a development project working on plans for a two-screen, touch-sensing device that could be used to read electronic books and take notes.

headline: Cap and Trade Loses in Australia
summary: The Rudd government bows to political reality.

headline: Celebrities in New York City
summary: Heard & scene on the latest celebtiry news.

headline: Patent Deals Lift Kodak
summary: Eastman Kodak reported a first-quarter profit on recent patent deals and a rebound in revenue, but the company said it continues to face depressed consumer demand.

headline: Higher Oil Prices Lift Exxon
summary: Exxon Mobil's first-quarter earnings rose 38% amid rising oil prices. Conoco's profit more than doubled, while Occidental's nearly tripled.

headline: EU Nears Aid Deal for Greece
summary: Germany's three main opposition parties agreed to fast-track consideration for $11.08 billion in German aid for its debt-laden euro-zone partner.

headline: U.S. Probes Boston Hospital Over Rates
summary: U.S. investigators are looking into Partners HealthCare Systems to determine if the operator of Mass. General Hospital and others hospitals violated antitrust rules in negotiations with health-care insurers.

headline: Pritzker Family Sells 51% Stake in TransUnion
summary: The Pritzker family said it sold a 51% stake in TransUnion to Madison Dearborn, in a deal valuing the consumer credit-reporting company at more than $2 billion.

headline: ArcelorMittal Gets Tough
summary: ArcelorMittal swung to a profit and said it plans to begin a round of price increases as global markets recover.

headline: The Pies That Bind
summary: The Buzzelli family bonds over pizza-making, and eating, in their Virginia home's remodeled kitchen, featuring a lovely wood-fired brick oven.

headline: Homeless Camp Vacated Ahead of Obama Visit
summary: A group of about 20 homeless people were told by state police to vacate a campsite they'd set up near an interstate highway as the University of Michigan is preparing to host Obama for a commencement address.

headline: Rolling Toward a Better Burger
summary: Serving grass-fed burgers and hand-cut fries, the Frites'N'Meats food truck claims it is saving the world, one burger at a time.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: 2,000 Guineas odds

headline: Los Angeles Lures Chinese Auto Firm
summary: Chinese auto maker BYD agreed to open its first U.S. headquarters in Los Angeles, as the company gears up for the rollout of electric vehicles.

headline: Another Cameron Late Show
summary: In a wild campaign, it's hard to say if David Cameron's solid performance in the third U.K. leader's debate will make any difference. But if the Conservatives can pull out a victory, it will have a lot to do with a typically last-minute recovery Thursday night.

summary: At home with the Buzzellis as they fix wood-fired pizzas in their remodeled kitchen.

summary: Read an excerpt from "Stuff: Compulsive Hoarding and the Meaning of Things" by Randy O. Frost and Gail Steketee.

headline: CFTC Fines Morgan Stanley, UBS Over Oil Block Trade
summary: The CFTC settled administrative charges against units of Morgan Stanley and UBS that alleged that Morgan Stanley had concealed a large crude-oil block trade last year with UBS's help.

headline: The Final Debate: Experts' Scorecard
summary: Experts give marks out of 10 for leaders looking to get into 10 Downing St.

headline: Chicago's Museum of Contemporary Art Names New Chief Curator
summary: Michael Darling, a curator at the Seattle Art Museum, is moving to the Windy City—he was named earlier today to be chief curator of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.

headline: Gulf Oil Spill Spreads
summary: Federal officials say the oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico is spreading and could reach the Mississippi River delta as early as Thursday night. The prospects for slowing the spread appear dim, and the slick threatens significant environmental damage.

headline: Banks' Capital Bill Under Overhaul Package: $85 Billion
summary: Large banks could face an $85 billion capital deficit if certain elements of the federal government's financial overhaul package are passed, according to one of the first reports from Wall Street analysts on the impact of the bill.

headline: Dow, Led by AmEx, Up 122.05
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped, driven by strong earnings reports and data showing improving manufacturing conditions in the Midwest.

headline: Baidu Profit Doubles on Google
summary: Baidu's first-quarter profit more than doubled as it benefited from the conflict between Beijing and Google, and a new advertising system.

headline: Foundation Offers $2.5 Million to Relocate School
summary: The Annenberg Foundation is offering $2.5 million to help pay for the relocation of an elementary school located near the recent mining accident that killed 29 miners.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended April 23 amounted to 21.7% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.5 billion shares, or 543 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Lionsgate Sees Strong Earnings
summary: Lionsgate, under takeover pressure from activist investor Carl Icahn, said it expects fiscal-year earnings to jump 53% on strong results in its television, record library and home-entertainment businesses.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Toyota Resumes Sales of Lexus GX 460
summary: Toyota said it resumed U.S. sales of the 2010 Lexus GX 460 sport-utility vehicle, which it recalled last week over rollover concerns, after sending dealers a repair kit.

headline: Bristol-Myers Lifts Profits, Cuts Outlook
summary: Bristol-Myers' first-quarter profit jumped 16%, but the drug maker trimmed its full-year forecast because of costs from the U.S. health-care overhaul.

headline: Australia Takes Aim at Tobacco
summary: Australia's government said Thursday it plans to ban brand labels and other marketing imagery on cigarette packaging by 2012, a move that would erase iconic logos like Marlboro's red-and-white chevron from store shelves.

headline: Oakley Helps Boost Luxottica Net
summary: Sports-eyewear company Oakley turned in a star performance as parent Luxottica posted a 21% increase in net profit.

summary: By Scott Turow

headline: Ash Cloud Cost Lufthansa $260 Million
summary: German flagship airline Deutsche Lufthansa lost almost $260 million when a volcanic ash interrupted air travel across Europe for nearly a week.

headline: Premier League TV Deal Reached
summary: BSkyB struck a deal with its regulator that lets three rival U.K. broadcasters show Premier League soccer matches, but BSkyB will continue to fight the wider ruling that it must wholesale content at regulated prices.

headline: IMF Boosts Asia Growth Forecast
summary: The IMF expects Asia's economic growth this year and next to be slightly higher than its recent estimates because of upward revisions to Singapore's forecasts, but cautioned Asian policy makers to guard against potential bubbles in local asset markets.

headline: Europe Gains as Fears Abate
summary: Stocks rose as investors cheered a slew of upbeat economic and corporate releases, amid growing hopes that a rescue deal for Greece was finally in sight.

headline: Oil Rises on Recovery Hopes
summary: Crude-oil futures settled at a two-week high, buoyed by a dip in U.S. weekly unemployment claims and hopes that economic recovery will lift petroleum demand.

headline: Obama Nominates Three to Fed Board
summary: Obama announced the nomination of two economists and a lawyer to the Fed Board, reshaping the central bank's top ranks at a critical period for financial regulation and monetary policy.

headline: Private Equity Will See Hope in Amadeus
summary: The IPO of Amadeus in Europe will lift buyout groups' spirits following a series of pulled deals earlier this year.

headline: Symantec Pays $370 Million for Two Security Firms
summary: Symantec agreed to buy two privately held email- and data-encryption companies for a total of $370 million in cash.

headline: Aetna's Profit Rises on Gains
summary: Aetna's first-quarter earnings rose 29% on gains from investments and the reversal of prior reserves, but membership fell.

summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: How to Join Obama on the Podium
summary: The University of Michigan held a contest to choose a student to speak with the president at commencement. at Commencement. Some students wanted to lay bare their fears about a wobbly economy. Then there was the shout-out to roommates for having a beer ready.

headline: Brazil Growth Lifts Santander
summary: Santander's first-quarter net profit rose 5.7%, driven by strong growth at its Brazilian unit and, to a lesser extent, in the U.K.

headline: Citi Europe Research Head Exits
summary: The head of European equity research at Citigroup resigned from the U.S. bank, amid a revived talent war for top stock analysts.

headline: Sateri Plans Hong Kong IPO
summary: Wood-based specialty cellulose manufacturer Sateri International Group plans to raise US$1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering in the second half of the year.

headline: Bond Traders Face Middle-of-the-Night Trading After U.K. Election
summary: Banks in the U.K. are planning to staff their government-bond trading desks from shortly after midnight on May 7, as the outcome of the U.K.'s general election is more uncertain than at any time since 1992.

headline: Viacom's Profit Rises
summary: Viacom's first-quarter earnings rose 38%, reflecting an improved advertising market.

headline: European Shares Rise on Earnings, Greece
summary: European stocks rose as investors cheered a slew of upbeat economic and corporate releases, amid growing hopes that a rescue deal for Greece is finally in sight.

headline: Harman International Industries, Pacific Capital Bancorp: Biggest Price Decliners (HAR, PCBC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Gold Prices Pull Back
summary: Gold futures were weaker as some traders sell to book profits after the market ran to its highest levels of the year this week.

headline: IPG Loss Narrows Slightly
summary: Interpublic Group, struggling to recover from the recession's flight of ad-spending dollars, reported a first-quarter loss that was slightly narrower than a year earlier.

headline: Honda Boosts Buyer Incentives
summary: Honda Motor has boosted buyer incentives in the U.S. to spur sales after an uneven first quarter, bringing it closer to the industry average for such offers.

headline: New Products Lift Unilever Results
summary: New products such as Dove soap for men and Magnum Gold ice cream helped Unilever post a 33% jump in net income, as CEO Paul Polman continued his strategy of holding down prices to drive volume growth.

headline: Oakley Helps Boost Luxottica Net
summary: Sports-eyewear company Oakley turned in a star performance as parent Luxottica posted a 21% increase in net profit.

headline: Audit of Agricultural Bank of China Finds Irregularities
summary: An official audit of Agricultural Bank of China found irregularities involving billions of dollars of loans on its 2008 balance sheet. While the amounts are small compared to its total assets, it could increase scrutiny of its practices when it seeks a stock-market listing, possibly later this year.

headline: Barclays Lays Off 250 India Staff
summary: U.K.-based Barclays has laid off about 250 employees in India in the final leg of reducing its work force as it shifts focus to wealthy clients from the mass market.

headline: Gazprom's Full-Year Net Rises
summary: Russia's Gazprom, the world's largest producer of natural gas, posted a 4.9% increase in full-year net profit, boosted by a paper gain on a revaluation of its oil unit Gazprom Neft.

headline: Kellogg Profit Jumps
summary: Kellogg's first-quarter profit jumped 30%, as revenue grew and margins widened on cost savings. Sales rose 4.7%.

headline: Siemens Lifts Outlook
summary: Siemens posted a 54% rise in net profit as restructuring measures boosted margins, and raised its guidance for the year.

headline: Time Warner Cable's Net Jumps
summary: Time Warner Cable reported a 30% jump in first-quarter earnings, aided by increases in advertising and total subscribers.

headline: India Cuts Service Tax on Construction
summary: India's Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee offered to reduce service taxes on the construction sector and announced a fresh debt relief plan for coffee growers.

headline: ANZ Profit Rises 36%
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group's fiscal first-half net profit rose 36% from a year earlier, boosted by lower charges for bad loans and higher profit margins.

headline: Iraq Accuses Kuwait of Impeding Flights
summary: The Iraqi government accused Kuwait of impeding the resumption of flights between Baghdad and London, urging Arab nations to intervene to prevent such "Kuwaiti practices."

headline: Crestor, Seroquel Boost AstraZeneca
summary: AstraZeneca said net profit rose 29% in the first quarter, helped by strong sales of the drugs Crestor and Seroquel and a lower tax rate. But the company warned that it faces a tougher second half of 2010.

headline: Fortune Brands' Net Surges
summary: Fortune Brands' first-quarter profit surged as the maker of Jim Beam whiskey, Moen Faucets and Titleist golf clubs reported a 13% jump in sales jump.

headline: Portugal: Can Cover Redemptions
summary: Portugal will have no difficulties covering its sizeable debt redemptions in May, despite worsening conditions on capital markets, the head of the country's treasury said.

headline: S&P: Europe's Banks Face $121.45 Billion in Property-Loan Losses
summary: European banks face up to €92 billion ($121.45 billion) in losses from commercial real-estate loans in the U.K., Ireland and Spain between 2009 and 2011 despite a recent rebound in property values, according to Standard & Poor's.

headline: Learn to Love the Goldman Inquisition
summary: There's nothing like a good Congressional hearing such as the one this week over the practices at Goldman Sachs to put the issues surrounding the financial crisis in perspective.

headline: Bunge Swings to Profit on Sales
summary: Bunge swung to a profit on revenue growth and improved margins, although volume dipped slightly. The farm-products company also cut its 2010 earnings target.

headline: International Paper Posts Loss
summary: International Paper swung to a loss on a plant-shutdown charge as higher costs pressured margins.

headline: Dubai World Lenders to Get 2% Interest on Debt
summary: Dubai World creditors are being offered a total 2% interest on the group's $23.5 billion debt excluding Dubai government claims and a shortfall guarantee from the government of Dubai.

headline: Becton Dickinson Earnings Rise
summary: Becton Dickinson said its profit rose 14% on strong sales in its medical and biosciences segments, but it lowered projected earnings for the year.

headline: Burger King Profit Falls 13%
summary: Burger King said its profit fell 13% on a decline in same-store sales, though customer traffic at U.S. stores turned positive in March as weather improved.

headline: Discounts Damp SK Telecom's Result
summary: SK Telecom, South Korea's top wireless carrier, said its first-quarter net profit rose 1.6% from a year earlier but sharply increased marketing costs and discounts hurt its operating profit.

headline: Rebound Evades France Télécom
summary: France Télécom reported lower first-quarter earnings and revenue as regulatory pressure continued to weigh on the group, but confirmed its full-year targets.

headline: BAA Posts Smaller Loss
summary: BAA, which owns London's Heathrow and Stansted airports, said earnings improved, but the six-day closure of U.K. airspace earlier this month will reduce 2010 earnings by $42.5 million.

headline: Adderall Patent Expiration Hits Shire
summary: Shire reported a 22% decline in profit because of lower sales of a former top seller no longer protected by patent, but earnings were cushioned by rising sales of newer drugs.

headline: Asia Stocks Fall on Europe Woes
summary: Major Asian markets ended mostly lower Thursday as concerns about spreading European debt woes dragged down regional shares, although beaten-down Chinese banks found buyers after a string of declines.

headline: Euro-Zone Business Confidence Improves
summary: Business confidence in the 16 countries that share the euro rose to its strongest level for almost two years in April and consumers were also slightly more upbeat.

headline: Starwood Reports Improving Demand
summary: Starwood Hotels' first-quarter earnings soared on prior-year charges as the lodging company saw demand continue to strengthen.

headline: FAA Seeks Fixes for Bombardier
summary: Federal air-safety regulators on Thursday are slated to issue a safety directive intended to prevent potentially hazardous stalls of certain Bombardier Q400 turboprops while flying in icy conditions.

headline: Russia Cuts Key Rate to Record Low
summary: Russia's central bank lowered key interest rates for the 13th time in a year in what may be the final cut in the country's current easing cycle.

headline: VW Brand Turnaround Lifts Group
summary: Volkswagen posted a 61% rise in first-quarter net profit and reiterated that some of the group's key numbers in 2010 are expected to be higher than in 2009.

headline: Pernod Ricard Raises Forecast
summary: French wine and spirits company Pernod Ricard raised its full-year sales outlook after increased demand in emerging markets, Russia and the U.S. drove revenue 14% higher.

headline: Acer Posts 62% Profit Rise
summary: Taiwan's Acer Inc., the world's No. 2 personal computer maker by shipments, reported strong profit gains for the first quarter, providing further evidence of the return of corporate demand to the industry.

headline: China Unicom Profit Falls 68%
summary: China's only iPhone operator, China Unicom, said first-quarter unaudited net profit fell to $165.6 million on depreciation and costs associated with its 3G business.

headline: India Food Prices Ease a Bit
summary: India's food prices snapped a five-week rising streak as fruits and wheat turned cheaper, raising hopes of a continued cooling off following forecasts of a normal monsoon.

headline: India Stocks: Agony & Ecstasy
summary: Here are some snapshots of Indian stock brokers, traders and investors reacting to the numerous ups and downs on Dalal Street in the last two years.

headline: Algeria Opposes MTN-Orascom Deal
summary: Algeria's government is opposing a deal under which South Africa's MTN Group would acquire the prized Algerian unit of Egypt's Orascom Telecom.

headline: Charges Offset BG's Output Increase
summary: BG Group posted a 4.8% fall in net profit as a loss from the sale of U.S. power plants and lower natural-gas prices offset an increase in the company's production.

headline: Hexaware Profit Drops 33%
summary: India's Hexaware Technologies posted a 33% drop in its first-quarter consolidated net profit, but forecast robust revenue growth in the current quarter as it expects more outsourcing orders on a spike in technology spending by clients.

headline: In the Kitchen With Chef Gray Kunz
summary: The celebrated chef of New York's Lespinasse is now in Hong Kong at Café Gray Deluxe, the restaurant of the Upper House hotel. Go behind the scenes with a him as he gives us a tour of his 3,000-square-foot kitchen.

headline: Patni Profit Soars
summary: Patni Computer Systems posted a near twofold jump in first-quarter net profit, but said too much cost cuts to overcome the economic slowdown has dented the software exporter's resources to gain from improved business conditions.

headline: BASF's Net Soars on Rising Demand
summary: German chemical giant BASF said it expects higher profit and sales in 2010 after first-quarter results beat estimates, but warned that economic recovery remains "shaky."

headline: Henry Paulson's $4.6 Million House
summary: See photos of the former Treasury Secretary's three-bedroom house in Washington, D.C. It was built in 1940 and gut-renovated in 2001.

headline: Diabetes Drug Boosts Sanofi's Net
summary: Sanofi-Aventis posted an 8.6% rise in fourth-quarter net profit, lifted by its diabetes drug Lantus, acquisitions and a boost from sales of A H1N1 flu vaccines and said it is on track to meet its full year target.

headline: Rory Medcalf: India Ahoy
summary: Building a navy to cement alliances and—perhaps more important—try to manage China's rise.

headline: Judge Has Record on Abortion Issue
summary: Diane Wood, a Chicago federal appellate judge who is on the White House's list of candidates for the latest high-court vacancy, has expressed approval for the philosophy behind Roe v. Wade.

headline: City Lets Air Out of Tennis Bubble
summary: The city's Department of Parks and Recreation is abandoning a plan to erect four bubble roofs over Central Park's 26 tennis courts between 94th and 96th streets.

headline: It's OK to Exhale, Jerry
summary: The pressure on manager Jerry Manuel has eased since the Mets swept the Dodgers to become number one in the NL.

headline: First Offshore Wind Farm Is Approved
summary: The Obama administration approved what would be the first U.S. offshore windmill farm, delivering a major victory for the wind energy industry after years of delays.

headline: No Dogs Can Mean No Sale in the City
summary: As the real-estate market attempts to regain its footing, some are finding that old anti-dog biases are hard to break.

headline: Bejing Revises Law on State Secrets
summary: China's legislature approved a revision to the country's law on state secrets that makes more explicit the responsibilities of government agencies—and companies—to help protect a range of sensitive information.

headline: Visa Net Climbs 33% As Spending Picks Up
summary: Visa's fiscal second-quarter profit grew by a third, topping analysts' expectations, as consumers ratcheted up spending and the company processed more payments.

headline: Sempra Settles California Dispute
summary: Sempra Energy and a partner agreed to pay a total of $410 million to the State of California to settle accusations that the companies overcharged for electricity.

headline: Singh, Gilani Make Little Progress
summary: Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh's meeting with his Pakistan counterpart, Yousuf Raza Gilani, ended Thursday with pledges to improve relations but no substantive progress toward that goal.

headline: Moscow Releases Katyn Documents
summary: Russian President Medvedev ordered his government to release once-secret documents on the 1940 Katyn massacre of 22,000 Polish prisoners to Warsaw, the latest step in a warming trend in ties with Poland.

headline: Gartmore Manager Reinstated
summary: Gartmore Group shares surged after the U.K. fund manager reinstated Guillaume Rambourg, the portfolio manager it suspended a month ago for a suspected breach of internal rules.

headline: On a Tattered Shoestring
summary: Chicago Opera Theater is known for its offbeat repertoire and smaller, imaginative productions. This season's offerings, however, suggest that even a shoestring operation needs a minimum level of resources.

headline: Financial Shares Slip
summary: European stocks tumbled after Standard Poor's downgraded its debt rating on Spain, compounding sovereign debt fears just as a resolution to Greece's aid package seemed to be in sight.

headline: Fortune's Ambassador
summary: In "Moses Montefiore," Abigail Green tells the story of a great Jewish philanthropist of the 19th century. Walter Laqueur reviews.

headline: Case Could Expand Legal Privilege in EU
summary: A case in which investigators seized emails between an employee of a company suspected of cartel behavior and the company's in-house lawyer is testing the rules on legal privilege in Europe.

headline: Cooks' Case Closed
summary: A federal appeals court on Wednesday rejected an author's arguments that comedian Jerry Seinfeld's wife copied her book on how to sneak fruits and vegetables into children's food.

headline: What's Behind New Bag Fees
summary: Despite widespread outrage, Spirit Airlines says it will charge fees on carry-on bags of up to $45 per passenger on Aug. 1. Besides the extra money, there's another reason for the new fee: No room at the (overhead) bin.

headline: UPS and FedEx Should Compete on Same Labor Field
summary: With your editorial "The Big Brown Union Bailout" (April 26), the Journal has bought into a fundamentally distorted view of efforts by Congress to level the competitive playing field in the express delivery business.

headline: RBS Incentive Plan Approved
summary: RBS shareholders, including the U.K. government, approved a new long-term incentive plan for executives after the bank was pressured to raise the share-price target that would trigger part of the payouts.

headline: Gates Takes Stake in Drug Development
summary: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates has made a small investment in a pharmaceutical-software maker, in a bid to reinvigorate a quest to use computers to revolutionize drug development.

headline: Water Strains Ease—for Now
summary: Abundant winter rains have largely refilled Bay Area reservoirs, bringing relief to a drought-weary region. But engineers warn that this year's bounty is probably only a brief respite.

headline: ER's Last Episode Unclear
summary: The handful of doctors, nurses and physician assistants on the overnight shift at St. Vincent's Hospital have not yet been given instructions on exactly how to shut down the Greenwich Village institution at 8 a.m. Friday.

headline: Court Says Cross Can Remain
summary: The Supreme Court reversed a lower court decision that could have required removal of a cross that has stood in California's Mojave National Preserve for generations.

headline: Mystery Rules at Edgar Awards
summary: Winners at tonight's annual Edgar Awards, presented by the Mystery Writers of America, should relish the victory—the first Edgar is often the last.

headline: Obama Sees Delay on Immigration Plan
summary: President Obama said Wednesday that Congress may not have the stomach to take on illegal immigration this year, despite efforts in the Senate to jump-start the issue.
